title: Active Scanning
content: Active scanning means systematically gathering information using structured patterns rather than passive observation. Effective operators use deliberate scan patterns—checking specific indicators in a consistent sequence—to ensure nothing is missed. The discipline of structured scanning is what separates noticing problems early from discovering them only after they've escalated.

mcq.question: During a busy shift, you rely on your usual habit of checking whatever catches your attention. A colleague uses a written checklist to monitor the same indicators every 30 minutes. After two hours, who likely has better situational awareness?

options.A: You, because flexible attention catches unexpected problems
options.B: Your colleague, because structured scanning ensures consistent coverage
options.C: Equal, since both approaches detect the same information
options.D: Neither, scanning frequency matters more than method

mcq.explanation: Structured scanning ensures all critical indicators are checked regularly, regardless of what seems interesting at the moment. Attention-driven scanning tends to miss slowly developing problems that don't immediately stand out.

openQuestions: What is your current scanning pattern during routine operations? Is it structured or opportunistic?
Which indicators in your work environment are most likely to be missed without deliberate, scheduled checking?
